Since I didn’t sign the offer and had questions, and counter offered I was declined the position. She blamed me for not showing urgency and not doing research. I feel like when you are wanting a good loyal employee that one shouldn’t be rushed. I can understand what I did wrong by not showing so called “urgency” but she didn’t acknowledge my questions after I reviewed the offer. So it makes you think how they treat employees overall. Maybe it’s a political game or they are just about numbers, and not hiring potentially loyal employees.
Interview Questions: What are your strengths?

title: Assistant Clinical Research Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at UC San Francisco in Jul 2018
Interview Descriptions: I had three interviews for a ACRC position at the Memory and Aging Center. The first one was friendly and one-on-one with the senior coordinator followed by a second where I interviewed with the entire lab team minus the PI and the final interview was with the PI. They asked why I was interested in their projects. It’s helpful to read papers published out of their labs to have a good familiarity with their studies.  I was offered the position and the three interviews were held over the course of two weeks.
Interview Questions: Why are you interested in our research?

title: Volunteer Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in May 2018
Interview Descriptions: We organized a time to meet, and we had a Skype interview. We emailed briefly before to set it up. The interview lasted about 20 minutes because we mostly communicated through email.
Interview Questions: What was your previous experience in the lab?

title: Administrative Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Apr 2018
Interview Descriptions:
I submit my resume to an online application process, with an option of importing your LinkedIn profile. I received an email as well as a phone message confirming receipt of online application and if interested in the position, a date and time for a phone interview. After phone screening, which lasted 30 minutes, we agreed to a date and time for a 1:1.  

PLEASE NOTE: the online application can take months without any guarantee of a response. Its worth noting that it is always best to get an employee referral. This is a large entity, and this stage of the application is like submitting into a black hole!
Interview Questions: General overview of your resume - tell your story in less that 2-3 minutes. This is the time to perfect your elevator pitch. Come prepared to ask questions as well as do your research on those who will be interviewing you.

title: Project Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Mar 2018
Interview Descriptions: It depends on the department you are going to work with. Every department is different and can vary vastly. It also depends which campus you will be working at and the type of work, whether it's clinical or non-clinical.
Interview Questions: Describe how you would handle a certain type of project and walk them through how you would handle the situation with your team.

title: Social Work Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at UC San Francisco
Interview Descriptions: I applied a position with 2 openings. I got called in twice for both of interview. I met with a same person with different group of interviewers with “a same exact set of questions” for an interview I. The way they arrange the interview is completely inefficiency.
Interview Questions: How long you will be committed to the position when you got hired?

title: Graduate Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. I interviewed at UC San Francisco
Interview Descriptions: Interviewed via skype. Very relaxed interview, typical questions regarding past employment and applicable experience. Small talk was actually refreshing. Only had one interviewer, the principal investigator of the lab. Not a lot of detail on the lab was given in terms of how many other employees, how large the lab is, what project I would be joining. I was given time to ask questions though, so I covered those.
Interview Questions: Describe what you will contribute to the lab.

title: Postdoctoral Fellow Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at UC San Francisco
Interview Descriptions: The process was friendly in itself.  However, expect long delays in correspondence. I had the opportunity of interacting one on one with all lab members. The members took me out to dinner at the end.  I enjoyed the lab's collaborative and supportive outlook.  The university itself has many wonderful opportunities to offer.
Interview Questions: How would you summarize the lab's outlook and theme?

title: Clinical Research Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Nov 2017
Interview Descriptions: The process took about a month from submitting application to receiving an offer letter. I applied for the position and within a week received an email to set up a Phone Interview. I had a phone interview with the hiring manager. After the phone interview, the hiring manager invited me for an in-person interview to meet with two other coordinators and the director. They asked me behavioral questions and inquired about my previous jobs. The coordinators went over the the daily task of the position and challenges they currently faced.
Interview Questions: What challenges did I come across when working in research?

title: Clinical Research Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Oct 2017
Interview Descriptions: I was finally called about 3 months after submitting applications to several different departments. Hopefully, I will be able to move forward in the hiring process, but there are a lot of other candidates being interviewed as well, I was told.
Interview Questions: What accomplishment are you most proud of in your professional life?

title: Clerk Interview
Application Type: I applied through a staffing agency. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (Richmond, CA) in Sept 2017
Interview Descriptions: The interview last about 30-45 minutes. I was asked mostly behavioral questions. At the end of the interview, they give you time to ask questions about them and time to take in feedback.
Interview Questions: Tell me about a time that you had a conflict with a peer or client and how did you handle it?

title: Human Resources Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA)
Interview Descriptions: I applied on the UCSF website and was contacted a few days later. It was a little confusing because there were multiple HR roles open and so two different recruiters contacted me for the same role but just from different departments. I had two phone interviews for both roles, and was then invited to come onsite for the roles, separately. The way that they interview is completely outdated.  You're sitting in a room with 4-5 people on the other side of the table and each interviewer basically goes down the line and reads a question to you from a piece of paper.  I always thought I was a good interviewer but I was definitely having problems with remembering the questions that they would read to me. It was pretty intimidating. Both of the interviews went that way.  The hiring managers said that they liked me, but it took them almost a month to get back to me to tell me that they hired someone for the roles I interviewed for, but they thought I would be a good candidate for yet another HR role. The recruiter asked if I'd be interested in interviewing for it and I decided to just move on because the thought of going through a third interview panel didn't seem like something that I wanted to do again and it seemed like the hiring process takes forever.
Interview Questions: Tell us how you would help someone with a question about a policy.

title: Officer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (Oakland, CA) in Jun 2017
Interview Descriptions: Pretty straight forward; three rounds at the Foundation offices. Spoke with multiple team members and the Chief Development Officer. Spent the majority of time with the Senior leader on the team I was interviewing for.
Interview Questions: What contribution would you make to this team?

title: SRA I Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Jun 2017
Interview Descriptions: Interviews will heavily depend on the specific group you are applying to work with, so I am not sure how this information will be useful. However, I can tell you for sure that the interview will be scheduled with each individual PI for a research position and will vary greatly depending  on  their personality.
Interview Questions: What are some of the techniques you performed int he lab as an undergraduate?

title: Assistant Clinical Research Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at UC San Francisco
Interview Descriptions: Interview was great, very professional, felt very casual. Usually starts off with a skype or phone screen, in my experience it's mostly phone screens first. Then you have an in-person with the recruiter who usually shows you around. Afterwards you either get declined through email, asked for a second round, job offer, or just silence which means you didn't get it.
Interview Questions: Why are you choosing this specific field?

title: Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in May 2017
Interview Descriptions: People were nice, but overall was quite disorganized. The first interview was pleasant, but the second interview  was canceled while we were still in the process of scheduling because the candidate had already been selected.
Interview Questions: How do you identify a tumor as cancerous? How do you determine if a particular drug can treat it?

title: Junior Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. I interviewed at UC San Francisco in Apr 2017
Interview Descriptions: My phone interview with the PI lasted about 45 minutes. She asked about my research interests, qualifications, and research experience. In addition, she asked me to share my strengths/weaknesses, my work environment preferences, etc.
Interview Questions: Are you comfortable handling animals?

title: Postdoctoral Fellow Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. I interviewed at UC San Francisco in Apr 2017
Interview Descriptions: They have a fairly standard postdoc interview process. You give a seminar, followed by a 15 min. Q & A. Then you have a 1h meeting with the PI, followed by 30 min. back to back meetings with members of the group. Lunch and dinner were included.
Interview Questions: Pretty standard questions to probe for your thoughts about your field and the lab's research

title: Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at UC San Francisco in Apr 2017
Interview Descriptions: using skype if you are not in CA, asked for the works you have done before in the lab and your interest fields, introduced the project they were doing and asked for some detailed technical questions
Interview Questions: do you have experience with AWS?

title: Lab Technician Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at UC San Francisco
Interview Descriptions: First is a pre-screen phone interview with the principal investigator's administrative assistant and then an in-person one on one interview with principal investigator -also met members of the lab at this moment
Interview Questions: Name a challenge and how you faced it.

title: Assistant Clinical Research Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Mar 2017
Interview Descriptions: First met with other coordinators who took me to coffee and described the position and the work/life balance. Then met one on one with doctors/senior coordinators from the clinic/research teams. Each asked similar questions mostly about my resume and past experiences. Was about 3 hours long.
Interview Questions: Expand on your college research experiences.

title: Staff Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Mar 2017
Interview Descriptions: Fairly straightforwards- apply online, submit CV and Cover letter, brought in for half day of interview with a number of people I would be interacting with. Received offer by email a week or two later, onboarding process was a slight pain but took a day of benefits and privacy review. Some number of online trainings specific to job description and institutional privacy and security. Completed all necessary onboarding in about a week.
Interview Questions: What are your long-term goals, why do you want to work in this lab, explain your past research experiences. Basic discussion of my technical capabilities, mostly conversation to test fit for lab culture and project team.

title: Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied through a recruiter. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Mar 2017
Interview Descriptions:
Cross functional panel interview. The whole process took the whole day. Everyone was very friendly. 
The questions were typical of an interview. Overall a good experience. I was hired so pretty happy about that.
Interview Questions: Please tell us about yourself?

title: Chemical Hygiene Officer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Feb 2017
Interview Descriptions: There was a panel of 3 people and the interview lasted for one hour at the EH and S building. Make sure you get there early, the parking was weird, plenty of spots available, just in a weird facilities road.
Interview Questions: What are the controls, hazards associated with using tert-butyl lithium?

title: Associate Professor Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Feb 2017
Interview Descriptions: Very technical and focused almost entirely on grant writing success and capacity.  Publication history dissected and questioned. Additional focus on participation in professional societies and think-tanks . Not much discussion of teaching.
Interview Questions: What leadership positions have you held in professional societies?

title: Research Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Feb 2017
Interview Descriptions: The interview was very straightforward, took about 30 minutes. Just mainly asked about my background in research and relative experiences. They mainly asked questions about things on my resume and to elaborate on what my daily tasks were. They also asked some technical questions about biology but nothing too specific.  Overall, it was not a tricky interview just stayed honest.
Interview Questions: Why are you interested in this position?

title: Clinical Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at UC San Francisco in Feb 2017
Interview Descriptions: Met with the lab advisor at a conference, discussed research goals and interests, along with current active projects in the lab. I had a good idea of their research and future interests, so the it was a good fit from the get-go. Recommendation to others is to directly reach out to the PI or head of the lab to discuss projects and interest before the interview.
Interview Questions: What excites you most about working in pediatric research?

title: Human Resources Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Feb 2017
Interview Descriptions: Telephone interview went well and I was told if it was up to the interviewer she would select me to move on to the next step of the interview process. I followed up with a Thank you letter and the reply I received was there were other candidates more qualified however my application will be active for future opportunities.
Interview Questions: Do you have any questions for me?

title: Clinical Research Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (Raleigh, NC) in Feb 2017
Interview Descriptions: I applied online, then I was contacted for a phone interview. Overall, the interviewer was pleasant, but I never heard back from the contact, even after emailing. The interview mostly consisted of behavioral questions.
Interview Questions: Why do you want to work with this lab?

title: CRC Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Feb 2017
Interview Descriptions: Phone interview was conducted by a representative of the lab. Very engaging and descriptive about the position.  Lab was committed to providing as much detail about their research and projects.
Interview Questions: What are you expectations and goals for this position? What kind of experience have you had in the past that you find applicable to this position?

title: Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Feb 2017
Interview Descriptions: Started with PI interview, then I had three different interviews with other lab mates. The questions were not too difficult, but I had to know the details of my research experience.
Interview Questions: What is your research background?

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. I interviewed at UC San Francisco in Jan 2017
Interview Descriptions: I had a wonderful conversation with the PI of the lab and the person who would be directly supervising me. It was warm and informative and I felt highly valued throughout the process. It was overall a great introduction for what turned out to be an incredible role.
Interview Questions: Why do you want to study neuroscience?

title: Clinical Research Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1+ week. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Jan 2017
Interview Descriptions: Phone screen, multiple in person interviews; 2 hours of behavioral questions from 2 separate coordinators but really nice people and very low key. They want people that can commit to around 2 years at least so I could not continue in the process since I wanted to apply to medical school before that. But the experience seems like a great one for someone who wants to go into a healthcare field. There is lots of patient interaction and you work closely with really intelligent and well known physicians.
Interview Questions: Tell me how you prioritize your tasks

title: Research Analyst I Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Dec 2016
Interview Descriptions:
Applied online. About a month later, the hiring manager called me to do a phone screen. A week after that, I had an in-person interview with the hiring manager and another manager, then a panel interview with three prospective coworkers. A month later, I was contacted for three references and a couple of weeks after that I was offered the position.

Both the phone screen and in-person interview were very easy and, despite the second interview being a panel, not nerve-wracking. They asked basic questions ("What's a weakness of yours?" "Why are you interested in this job?") and a few impromptu questions based on my resume.
Interview Questions: How you would respond if a person in authority asked you to do something that is in conflict with an established policy (e.g. HIPAA)?

title: IT Service Desk Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Nov 2016
Interview Descriptions: Received an email asking to interview me one month after I applied online. It was an interview with 2 people. They informed me that the position was not permanent.
Interview Questions: How do you stay up to date on current technology and trends?

title: Administrative Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (New York, NY)
Interview Descriptions: Someone called me at the department and had a phone interview with me. They did not reply to my emails after I followed up. I thought the least they can do it reply back to an email saying if they were going to follow through.
Interview Questions: How do you deal with a mean manager?

title: Research Associate I Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at UC San Francisco
Interview Descriptions: I applied for the job online and was contacted through email almost three months later to set up a phone interview. The phone interview was standard; the lab manager asked about my previous lab jobs and briefly described the responsibilities of the research associate position. If the phone interview went well, the manager would contact you to set up an in-person interview at the lab.
Interview Questions: Do you have experience working with a clinical population?

title: Senior Clinical Research Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Oct 2016
Interview Descriptions: Applied online in September 2016 and was invited to the PI's office in late October for a panel interview. Arrived for my interview which consisted of the PI and Co-PIs so three people in total. Each of them asked me a series of set interview questions they had prepared for each candidate so it was definitely structured. Panel interviews can be intimidating so I made sure to try to make each of them smile by closing with a funny. I think they liked it since they offered me the job.
Interview Questions: Where do you see yourself in 5 years?

title: Assistant Clinical Research Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Oct 2016
Interview Descriptions: I had a 15 minutes phone interview first and then was invited for an in-person interview the following week. I interviewed with four people from the department. I spoke with each person separately for about 15-20 minutes. It felt easygoing and conversational. They spent most of the time telling me about the position. Then they asked about my experience, as well as personal questions about my interests and hobbies. I was there for 2 hours total.  I didn't get the job, but it was still a positive experience.
Interview Questions: What do you like about research?

title: Practice Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at UC San Francisco in Oct 2016
Interview Descriptions: The interview was between supervisor and manager and it was an in-person 60 minutes interview. They asked behavioral/STAR questions and mainly focused on how you will deal with conflict and pressure,
Interview Questions: Explain a time where you had a conflict with a coworker and they were right

title: Administrative Assistant III Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 days. I interviewed at UC San Francisco in Oct 2016
Interview Descriptions: I submitted my resume via the UCSF jobs website. I received an email from the person I would be working for (not my technical supervisor), we coordinated an interview time, and then had a Skype interview. At the end they asked for a few references, who they contacted very shortly thereafter and then I received an offer early the following week. The entire process was pretty quick - i would say 4-5 days.
Interview Questions: What are some things you are good at, and where can you improve?

title: Junior Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Sept 2016
Interview Descriptions: Applied through Academic Recruiting, got an email from the PI, did a phone interview, visited the lab space, interviewed with the PI, interviewed with other PI's in the department and on the floor, was then called and emailed and offered the position and sent an offer letter. Then it took 1 month for onboarding/HR/etc.
Interview Questions: Technique questions, scientific principle questions

title: Fundraising Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Aug 2016
Interview Descriptions: The process was rigorous but it was effective. It began in July 2016 through the end of August 2016, 3 interviews in total. I received an offer mid September with a start date early October.
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Senior Project Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Jul 2016
Interview Descriptions: Easy and standard process.  Two interview sessions, each one hour and in person.  Hiring manager kept me updated.  HR does not notify you on the status of your application.
Interview Questions: Describe a time when a set back occurred, and what did you do to resolve it?

title: Assistant Animal Technician Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA)
Interview Descriptions: I was recommended for the job so I really did not have much of an interview.  I just got hired.  I was recommended by someone who was already working there and I interviewed with the Head of the Department.  He was very impressed with my communication skills and professionalism..
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Clinical Research Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at UC San Francisco
Interview Descriptions: The interview process was very simple and straightforward. All questions about past research and leadership experience. The first interview was a phone interview and the next one was on site. After the second interview I received my offer letter.
Interview Questions: Past experience, leadership skills

title: Staff Research Associate II Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA)
Interview Descriptions: I applied online through UCSF's website, I was contacted for a a phone interview which was followed by a one on one meeting with the Principal Investigator that was hiring me. The one on one interview had to do with my background in research, personal qualities, and desire to work at UCSF. During this interview I was given a tour of lab and facility, I also met with researchers and collaborators.
Interview Questions: Reason for applying as research associate instead of going to graduate school?

title: Database Manager II Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Jun 2016
Interview Descriptions: I went through the entire process of interviewing for the Database Manager II position (phone screen, on-site interview, meet the team, show samples of my work; they contacted my references). The UC system, as some may know, has a Title Code System with salary ranges for each listed job title. I was looking for a mid-range salary for the Database Manager II title, as is appropriate for both my work experience and listed position job title category. When it came time for the job offer, it turned out this particular office didn't have anything close to reasonable in mind for the salary offer and was looking to pay at the lowest range of the Database Manager II salary bracket. This was completely ridiculous and a thorough waste of my time. I hope not every department at UCSF treats its applicants this way, but this was a very negative experience for me.
Interview Questions: How would I ensure availability and security of their lab and patient data.

title: Postdoctoral Scholar Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in May 2016
Interview Descriptions: The interview process varies by professor. I had an in person interview at the Parnassus campus with the entire lab. The initial meeting with the PI was followed by a lab talk on my dissertation work followed by lunch. After lunch I had individual meeting with each lab member where we discussed the lab culture and the focus of each ongoing project.
Interview Questions: Which project was I the most interested in and how soon could I tell them if I will take the job.

title: Directory Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in May 2016
Interview Descriptions: Great and very straight forward. 3 step process, phone, then in person, then second round to hire. I first applied online and had to wait a good amount of time (nearly a month and a half) before an email was sent to me with additional requests and information on a phone interview.
Interview Questions: What is a marketing challenge you've tackled recently, and what steps did you take to satisfy all stakeholders?

title: Lab Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in May 2016
Interview Descriptions: I interviewed with the PI of the lab. It was very straightforward and casual. She asked me about my background, my experiences, availabilities, etc. The PI talked to me about what her projects are, and what responsibilities I would take on if I got the job. There was no phone screen prior to this -- the interview was set up through email.
Interview Questions: 1. Tell me about yourself. 2. Walk me through your resume. 3. Why this position/Why do you think you're a good fit?

title: Postdoctoral Researcher Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at UC San Francisco
Interview Descriptions: Presentation plus meeting different people plus seeing the lab around was a pretty good experience, also a lunch was included. I liked the place. I have recruited before and these guys seem very professional
Interview Questions: What do you want to do in future?

title: Staff Research Associate I Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Apr 2016
Interview Descriptions: Intense for a entry-to-mid level position. I had two phone interviews, two written or oral take-home exercises, and several hour-long phone calls discussing details of the position. Several days of work were required to complete the exercises. I unfortunately had to decline the offer due to unacceptably low pay, but the overall experience was very useful.
Interview Questions: The written exercise included re-working a draft survey protocol for use in the field.

title: Clinical Research Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 7 weeks. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Apr 2016
Interview Descriptions: I submitted an application for a CRC position and was contacted for a phone interview several weeks after. The phone interview went well and I was asked to send my references to the head of the lab. I was told I would be contacted again to schedule an in-person interview. My references were never contacted, and I didn't get a response to my email, or any follow up emails sent soon after/a few weeks later. I think more correspondence about the job status would have been the professional way to go about the situation.
Interview Questions: For the phone interview, questions were very standard; What interests you about this position, What are your previous experiences, What is your background, and so on.

title: Staff Research Associate I Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Apr 2016
Interview Descriptions: I was told I would be interviewed by the PI's but I was interviewed by the whole team so be prepared for that. One of the PI's showed me around the lab first and then sat me down with the whole team for an interview. They created a very comfortable environment for the interview and everyone was very nice.
Interview Questions: Tell me about your experiences working in a lab?

title: Clinical Research Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 8 weeks. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Mar 2016
Interview Descriptions:
Process took about 2 months from submitting my application to my verbal offer/offer letter. There was an initial phone screen and afterwards I was asked to come for in-person interviews. I met a lot of team members and had about 30 minutes one-on-one conversations with them. It felt more like conversations than interviews. I primarily had to experience behavioral interviews with the Lead CRCs but usually other team members would ask more personal questions. 

I was contacted by 3 departments at UCSF. Most departments are really nice but I felt a greater fit with the dept. that offered me the position. They care a lot about hiring someone who understands the job that they're getting into, someone who works hard and cares about patients.
Interview Questions: Tell me about yourself and how the position applies to your future goals.

title: Histotechnologiest Interview
Application Type: I applied through a staffing agency. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Mar 2016
Interview Descriptions: Through the contracting firm I was called for a screening interview. After that I was asked to interview with the group that I would be working with. I went through the standard interview questions being assked about myself and where I would see myself in 5 years time. What skills i posesed and how I utilized them to make myself better. After interview I was shown around the lab and got an offer within the week.
Interview Questions: How will your previous work experienced helped you to advance the efficiency of the lab?

title: Administrative Assistant III Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Feb 2016
Interview Descriptions: The interviewer was very pleasant and friendly, I felt comfortable right away. She asked basic interview questions and was very easy to talk to. She was happy to see I was already a University of California - Francisco employee, a definite plus. Very willing to help.
Interview Questions: What was the most difficult problem you had and what did you do to fix it?

title: Executive Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Feb 2016
Interview Descriptions: first there was a telephone interview, and then that was followed by a panel interview and then the last step was an interview with the head of the department for which I applied
Interview Questions: skill set

title: Training and Development Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at UC San Francisco
Interview Descriptions:
The hiring manager spent less than 30 minutes doing a phone screen.
I researched her credentials prior to the interview and saw that she's been with UCSF since 2000, and started as a payroll clerk.
Now she's the director of HR with no formal education and on the job experience.
How does that happen? 
I have an advanced degree and more than 20 years in the industry, including management. 
I got the feeling I was over qualified,  and am not sure why she bothered.
Interview Questions: How many years have you been working in this field?

title: Analyst I Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Jan 2016
Interview Descriptions: Was contacted via email to set up a phone interview, which lasted about 20 minutes. Asked standard questions regarding my resume information. A follow-up onsite meeting with staff was set up, and I met with direct supervisor as well as staff. I found it very curious that staff would opening discuss how nice everyone is, how easy the schedule is but nothing about what they do, opportunities to grow, interaction between other divisions within the department. I came away with the feeling that it was a very low achieving team who did not get any encouragement nor mentorship. I learned last person left after only a year. After the 30 minute meeting, I received an email invite to second job interview with faculty and director of division. This was a disappointing experience - I was very interested in the department and studied the organization and faculty I will be meeting, as well as prepared a list of questions that I wanted to ask. It was like 'speed dating' given only 10-15 minutes at the most to talk to each faculty, one of them kept me waiting outside his office because he was on the phone, which cut down our time to meet.
Interview Questions: Why do you want this job, with your experience and skills you will be bored.

title: Academic Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Jan 2016
Interview Descriptions: Took close to a month from initial sending out resume to start date. A lot of hoops to jump through to bring you onboard, but actual interview was fairly simple and casual, as a way to get to know you and to see if you have professionalism.
Interview Questions: What past experiences do you have that will make you succeed in this position?

title: Financial Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 6 weeks. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA)
Interview Descriptions: The process consisted of a phone interview and two rounds of in-person, panel interviews. It took about a month a half from first contact to offer. There was no salary negotiation- it was a take it or leave it offer (I took it); I tried to push for more but was unsuccessful. It was a stressful process (because, you know, interviewing), but looking back, it went very smoothly and was well handled by the organization.
Interview Questions: Pretty standard interview questions- Tell me about your experience? What are your strengths and weaknesses? Why do you want to work here? What makes you the best candidate for the job? What do you think are the major challenges of the new job? How would you go about learning your new job? How do you keep organized? Describe your ideal working environment. Describe a situation where you did all the right things but were still unsuccessful. And more...

title: Postdoctoral Scholar Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 6 months. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA)
Interview Descriptions: I had the on-site interview for two days. On the first day, met 5-6 faculty members, had lunch/dinner, and gave presentation. The second day, had a mini project to prove my research skill. It was bit tough but good to know people, project and how they work as team.
Interview Questions:
Q: What was your graduate research? 
Q: What was your research background?

title: Talent Acquisition Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied through other source. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Dec 2015
Interview Descriptions:
I had a phone screen, and then I was asked to come onsite for a panel interview. I met with five recruiters at once who were interviewing me for a recruiter position. The interview was awful because it was very mechanical. They literally took turns asking me a questions, word for word, from a document they had in front of them. These were all standard behavioral questions. Even though the questions were basic they were worded in an unclear way, as if hey were trying to be more difficult than they actually were.

It made me feel like they had no interviewing skills or personality. It was almost impossible for them to have a more natural feeling conversation that allowed them to learn about my experience. One of them even asked another what time my interview was over. I found that to be unprofessional and it contributed to a poor candidate experience. Overall, the panel wasn't very warm or friendly. They seemed tired, not very excited to be there, and the questions were robotic since they were reading from a document verbatim. 

I knew that I couldn't work in that kind of culture. Candidate experience is very important to me, and they don't seem to have down the basics yet. 

I withdrew from the interview process.
Interview Questions: What could happen to make you not want to work here in 6 months?

title: Postdoctoral Research Scientist Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Dec 2015
Interview Descriptions: I met the PI after an exchange of emails with CV.  He explained that someone got into University and so his job was available and they were screening applicants. He explained the requirements, education level, skills needed.
Interview Questions: It is hard to find a skilled technician. Would you be okay to work in a lab to learn a lot of new skills on this job and carry out lots of general lab work?

title: Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at UC San Francisco
Interview Descriptions: Took me around the lab and had me meet with each of lab members; asked me about what my career interests were and what I was planning to do in the next few years; Are genuinely interested in your career and seem to want people who are willing to stay there between 2-3 years.
Interview Questions: What are your career goals?

title: Clinical Research Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at UC San Francisco in Nov 2015
Interview Descriptions: UCSF was very flexible in scheduling my interview even when I had a trip planned. First a phone screening was done, and then I was called in for an interview. It felt very informal and more like a conversation.
Interview Questions: What make you want to be a research coordinator?

title: Postdoctoral Fellow Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Nov 2015
Interview Descriptions: It depends on the lab, usually get a phone interview with the PI, before invited for an on-site interview. A full day on site interview was scheduled. It began with my presentation, lunch with lab members and I talked to everyone in the lab.
Interview Questions: What projects are you planning to work?

title: Staff Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Nov 2015
Interview Descriptions:
- Applied online through their job portal system and was contacted a week later by an HR person (though I had already heard from the position from within; from a contact I had from a previous internship at UCSF)
- Asked for my availability, scheduled for an interview later that week
- Arrived at interview, met with a few people from the lab, and was taken around the campus and given a tour
- Called in for another round of interviews, this time with the PI of the lab
- Received a job offer a few days after
Interview Questions: Questions about previous lab experience, future career goals, why this lab, etc. Very basic questions (that are to be expected when applying) for a research position.

title: Post Doctoral Fellow Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at UC San Francisco
Interview Descriptions: One hour presentation on your current PhD work. Meet with the PI and then with other lab members individually. It is about a day long. I got lunch but did not have dinner with the lab.
Interview Questions: What I want to do in the lab at UCSF. What projects I am interested in.

title: Senior Director of Development Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 2 days. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Oct 2015
Interview Descriptions: 2 full days of interviews with approximately 20 different people.  From academic leadership to development leadership.  This included individual interviews as well as group panels.  The days started at 9 and interviews concluded at 5.
Interview Questions: They asked about my experience in fundraising.

title: Internal Audit Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Sept 2015
Interview Descriptions: The interview was very informal.  I met with audit director (who was very friendly and talkative) and a senior manager (who seemed very skeptical).  We  talked about background.  No case studies.  No little tests.
Interview Questions: Experience in the academic setting.

title: Health Navigator Interview
Application Type: I applied through other source. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at UC San Francisco
Interview Descriptions: It was via email and telephone - never made it to in person status. The process was quick and rather painless, with responsive communication. The website is easy to navigate but having a sense, generally, of where your application stands is more complicated than other UC schools I've worked with before.
Interview Questions: How would you communicate with your boss about an issue, for example, your boss has asked you to order something that is over the budget.

title: Peptide Chemist Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA)
Interview Descriptions: Arrived, met the CEO. 1st round interview then got underway. I met some people in the lab and the selection board (three people). Then had a series of questions and answers, including my background and work/achievements. 2nd round I gave my presentation including my scientific work and spoke I about what I could incorporate into the potential project. Then I got a phonecall and got an offer.
Interview Questions: Whats drives your passion for Science?

title: Research Analyst I Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at UC San Francisco
Interview Descriptions: had 3 sets of interviews via phone or Skype. the first interview was with the office manager, next was with a program manager, and last was with the PI. all interviews were fair, and they were all friendly. this process seems to weed out the candidates who are not suitable for this position.
Interview Questions: is there one example in your previous job where you encountered a moral dilemma? if yes, how did you handle it?

title: Programmer/Analyst II Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Aug 2015
Interview Descriptions: I had a phone interview with a coordinator. It took only two minutes since it was an on-site interview invitation. I had on-site interview with PI next week. The PI told me that she would let me know the result in two weeks, but she never contacted me or replied me for a month.
Interview Questions: The job is a part-time (50~80%). Is it okay for you?

title: Staff Research Associate II Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 days. I interviewed at UC San Francisco
Interview Descriptions: Emaling the supervisor you will be working for directly is much better than going through their site.  Their site is horrid and their filtering system will automatically reject all the applicants who dont have exactly the requirements.
Interview Questions: No surprises

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: The process took 1 week. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA)
Interview Descriptions: I emailed a bunch of professors, and just hoped for a reply. Fortunately, one did reply but at the same time, most did not. I would suggest others follow the same process. It is almost a guarantee that at least one will reply
Interview Questions: What are your plans for the future?

title: CIAQ Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at UC San Francisco in Jul 2015
Interview Descriptions:
Phone interview followed by an in person interview a couple of weeks later. The questions were fair and relevant to the job and mostly were just about my background experience. It seems like a great program and department to be in.

I do have a complaint, however this is more about the UCSF interviewing process in general and not specific to this position. Over the last few months I have interviewed for 7 jobs at UCSF and am now hearing from people that work here that often times candidates just get called in to meet the minimum criteria of HR. The candidate is usually already picked before people even come in. For other positions, I have experienced the hiring manager not showing up to my interview, being told by the interviewer that they don't know what to ask me, interviews only lasting 10 minutes (later I see the person they hired was already working there) and the interviewer not knowing what position I am there to interview for. I am now temping in a different department and I see this process going on internally. All of the people I have met through my interviews have been great, however it just seems like a waste of time for everyone to call somebody in when you are not even interested in the candidate and I don't see why HR requires this.
Interview Questions: Why do you think you would be a good fit for this position?

title: Clinical Research Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 5 months. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Jun 2015
Interview Descriptions: I have talked for about half an hour with chief of the department. It was clear from the beginning that I was overqualified and instead of giving me details about the job (she actually said she has multiple positions) she spent the entire time criticizing my education and pretty much everything else she saw in my resume. I have had a bunch of other job interviews at UCSF and I have always met nice people. This is actually the only bad experience I ever had there.
Interview Questions: tell me about the school where you graduated from

title: Clinical Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Jun 2015
Interview Descriptions: The interview process involved a phone interview and in person panel interview. The reviewers asked difficult questions that were personal and professional. The panel interview was an hour long.
Interview Questions: Why should we hire you

title: Administrative Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 5 days. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Jun 2015
Interview Descriptions: Interview was about one hour long, asked a variety of technical and general questions relevant to the job description and UCSF mission statement. Interview experience was comfortable, and not too scary.
Interview Questions: What is one of your weaknesses?

title: Junior Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Jun 2015
Interview Descriptions: fast paced interview. With a lot of questions on your previous research/work experience. Not so many questions on your understanding of the work the lab is currently doing though. Pretty easy process in general.
Interview Questions: What did you do in your previous research job?

title: Postdoctoral Scholar Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Jun 2015
Interview Descriptions: I presented my research in a one hour seminar and then met with 7 members of the group. For each person we talked about their research and I was able to ask them questions about the lab. I had lunch with three members of the lab as well. After the interview we went to dinner. Overall, pretty standard for an academic post-doc position.
Interview Questions: Technical questions about my reseach

title: Post Doctoral Employee Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Jun 2015
Interview Descriptions: Presentation plus meeting different people plus seeing the lab around was a pretty good experience, also a lunch was included. I liked the place. I have recruited before and these guys seem very professional
Interview Questions: What do you want to do in future?

title: Nurse Abstractor Field Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in May 2015
Interview Descriptions: Phone interview was easy standard questions not too stressful. Did not deal with HR at all. Just the department directly. They are extremely nice and professional. The position was temporary and it did not pay enough for me to accept they did attempt to meet me half way by increasing the offer four dollars but it wasn't up to par with my experience and education.
Interview Questions: Experience and supervisory training

title: Postdoctoral Scholar Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in May 2015
Interview Descriptions: Met personally. Invited to on-site interview (got paid flight ticket and hotel). Then, did presentation and skill interview since computational based work. Interview took a day with meeting several faculties and postdocs. It was an intense interview.
Interview Questions: General, research and technical questions.

title: Social Work Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in May 2015
Interview Descriptions: I applied online and was called within a few weeks.  I had a brief chat on the phone with an admin person, then two interviews.  Within two weeks I was offered the position.  The process moved pretty quickly.
Interview Questions: I was asked some clinical questions based off vignettes that were presented to me.

title: Marketing Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in May 2015
Interview Descriptions: First there was a request for a paragraph long response to a question via email, then a short phoe interview. After that there were two in person interviews both about 1.5 hours long.
Interview Questions: What is your management style?

title: Analyst I Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 6 weeks. I interviewed at UC San Francisco
Interview Descriptions: Submitted CV, emailed 3 weeks later, phone interview the following week. Asked to submit additional documents, was in touch with one of the interviewers about a job opening that was available but not the job I applied to, and applied for that job with her recommendation.
Interview Questions: Why are you interested in working for us?

title: Senior Telecommunications Engineer Interview
Application Type: I applied through a staffing agency. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Apr 2015
Interview Descriptions: I was interviewed by the Telecommunications Manager during the first interview, IU was brought back for a second and third panel interview and eventually was hired as a contractor although the position was advertised as a permanent position.
Interview Questions: They asked how I got started in the industry

title: Postdoctoral Fellow Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at UC San Francisco
Interview Descriptions: Phone interview, he talked about his research, i asked questions, what specific projects, funding conditions, lab members, collaboration etc. After the phone interview, he asked me to provide three reference letters the same day. After a week, he offered me the position and discuss what my potential start date would be.
Interview Questions: What is your strength and weakness? What is your research?

title: Administrative Assistant III Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 5 days. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Mar 2015
Interview Descriptions: I was phone interviewed with UCSF's internal Temporary Employment Service and sent to an in-person interview with the head of the department that needed a position filled immediately. I was told that day that I was great and was hired as a temp with a three-month assignment. After two months as a temp, I was given the role permanently with a title change to Administrative Analyst I.
Interview Questions: What did you do at this job (pointing to one of the jobs on my resume)?

title: Assistant Clinical Research Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Mar 2015
Interview Descriptions: Process took about two months. Referred in by another research coordinator. First interview, I met with a team of other coordinators, the project's manager who's an advanced practice nurse, and the principle investigator who's a neurologist. Interview was casual but long. Lots of basic and predictable interview questions from the coordinators. They seemed to be looking for someone who's proactive, sharp, can learn quickly, and is easy to work with. Skill/experience not a focus. After first interview, was strung along for a while and wouldn't get a response after several follow ups. Finally, I was told that I didn't get the position but that they wanted me to come in and interview for a different position. Came in again, very similar interview. Got a call the next day and was asked to come in and meet some other team members. Came in and had casual conversation with other coordinators and was offered the job the next day.
Interview Questions: Give an example of a time you had to deal with a difficult patient/client/coworker and how you solved the issue.

title: Patient Care Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Feb 2015
Interview Descriptions: I was contacted by e-mail/phone for interview in person. I presented for interview about a week later at the dental clinic. I only interviewed the head of the patients admission department. She told me from the beginning that I was overqualified and would not be good for the job. I was notified about the result a few days later
Interview Questions: Why are you considering this position? You seem to be overqualified!

title: Office Manager Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at UC San Francisco in Feb 2015
Interview Descriptions: Saw listings online, have to sign up to their site to apply and fill up a detailed application form natively on their site. Attach your files and send it in. They will mail you back but it might take a while.
Interview Questions: The forms asks about prior salaries, so be prepared to disclose those too.

title: Administrative Assistant III Interview
Application Type: I applied through a staffing agency. The process took 3 days. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Jan 2015
Interview Descriptions: I went through a temp agency. They set me up with an in person interview with the supervisor. I went to the campus, was directed to the office and was greeted by another employee in the office. The supervisor for that department interviewed me and the interview lasted about 30 minutes.
Interview Questions: Would you describe yourself as detail oriented?

title: Clinician Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Jan 2015
Interview Descriptions: Typical medical interview.  Laidback and nothing over the top.  As long as you are well trained and prepared this should be a breeze. The overall process consisted of one on one interviews as well as a panel.
Interview Questions: Questions regarding conflict management, clinical questions, typical interview questions.

title: Postdoctoral Fellow Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Jan 2015
Interview Descriptions: The interview took only a day. It was quick. I first presented my work to lab that I applied. Then I had a second interview with another professor in the department. Later I had a lunch with PI. Then I met all members of the lab. Finally I met the PI and he talked to me about projects I can work for. Next day I got the offer.
Interview Questions: I had to present my previous work. There were not any questions.

title: Administrative Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 3 days. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Jan 2015
Interview Descriptions: Process was quick and smooth. Only went in one time. Questions were challenging, but not difficult to answer if you have any background in dealing with clients and phone skills.
Interview Questions:
Can you work under pressure?
Can you handle several tasks at the same time?
What would you do if you don't understand a request from a client?

title: Administrative Assistant III Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at UC San Francisco
Interview Descriptions: Submitted my application online. Got a call from the office manager about my experience, what I was looking for in a position out of graduation, and if i was willing to move to San Francisco (I was in Orange County at the time.) Then came up to San Francisco and met with the office manager, the research director, one of the administrative assistants, and the doctor that I would be assisting. Everyone asked very typical questions like what skills do I have, what can I learn and contribute and where do I see myself going in the future.
Interview Questions: No curveballs, very straight forward.

title: EHS Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Dec 2014
Interview Descriptions: interviewed with the director. Most questions are about previous experience. Some technical questions and introduced the current projects that I will be working on. Negotiate the salary over phone a few days later.
Interview Questions: How to conduct air quality assessment

title: Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied through other source. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Dec 2014
Interview Descriptions: The interview process is all depend on your manager or your boss! Because it's university and each section is managed by different department and people! Also, all questions are coming from your backgrounds and your computer skills
Interview Questions: Are you good at programming? Can you prove it? How many publication do you have? How many conference paper do you have?

title: Study Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at UC San Francisco
Interview Descriptions: The process took about a month, with an initial phone screen interview and an in-person interview. The in-person interview was mostly a behavioral interview, with a few technical questions. The interviewers were professional and responsive, and the team seemed to be a close-knit and casual group. The work environment also seemed like good place for professional growth.
Interview Questions: Conceptual and technical questions relating to quantitative analysis.

title: Clinical Research Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA)
Interview Descriptions:
I interviewed for 5-6 different CRC jobs, all from online applications. I would typically get contacted within 1-3 weeks of submitting my application, either by email or phone (though I've gotten interview requests up to 2 months afterwards.) There would be a phone screen and then an in-person interview on site. The in-person interview would sometimes also involve the PI/doctor directing the project, or a number of other CRCs.  

There were usually no surprise questions. The people interviewing were, for the most part (with only 1-2 exceptions), very passionate about their work and just looking to hire the most qualified candidate. Interviews typically started with a more detailed description of the research and the position. They asked about my previous work experience, other activities, why I was interested in the job, where I saw myself a few years down the road, other typical things like that. What I found most challenging was honestly coming up with good questions, because the interviewers were generally very thorough in their position descriptions. Many of the interviewers did ask the strengths/weaknesses questions - be prepared with an answer and examples that tie in to the specific job duties. 

For a few of these positions, about a week after the in-person interview, I was asked to send over my references. About a week after that was when I was informed either of my rejection or acceptance (by phone call.) 

One of my interviews for a CRC position was a full hour-long behavioral interview with lots of questions including "three words to describe yourself" as well as the typical "tell me a time when..." etc, etc. I was actually very frustrated with this interview because we did not discuss the position in much detail, nor did the actual topic of research actually get brought up. That was a very disappointing experience, but the thing is, while CRC job listings all resemble each other very closely, each interview varies widely depending on the project and the people involved. Do your research and practice! Being familiar with the particular project is really the most important thing to prepare (as well as being ready to hash out your past in a relevant manner.) For the most part, however, I had good experiences - straightforward interviews with interested people who didn't want to waste time on irrelevant discussions. No trick questions, just honest talking - those were the interviewers I respected the most.
Interview Questions:
In the behavioral interview: Tell me about something you would now do differently if you had a chance to go back and change your decision. 
In normal interviews: a case question about what to do when you had to consent two patients but were short on time

title: Staff Research Associate III Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Oct 2014
Interview Descriptions: Submitted cover letter and resume to listed email address. Received a call back within a couple days for an initial phone interview. Was invited to 2 subsequent in-person interviews to meet with different stakeholders (imagine it would have been just 1 interview if all their schedules had aligned). Was offered a position within 2 days after last in-person interview. HR process takes about 2-3 weeks to complete in addition.
Interview Questions: Where do you see yourself in 5 years and how does this position play a role in achieving that?

title: Postdoctoral Scholar Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Oct 2014
Interview Descriptions: As this was an academic interview, I imagine the process is very specific to the PI interviewing. In my case it involved a phone interview with my PI, followed by an in person interview, where we discussed the role. I then met informally with a more senior PI, and other postdocs and research assistants in the lab. There was no interaction with HR or anyone from the university itself.
Interview Questions: Relevant questions about my PhD and previous research projects

title: Graduate Student Researcher Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 days. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA)
Interview Descriptions: I submitted my application online. The application packet included a resume, at least 3 letters of recommendation, and several essays and short answer questions (including questions about GRE scores and publication record). The submission deadline was sometime in November. I was called for an interview in January and interviewed on campus in early February. I interviewed with 5 faculty and 1 student in the Tetrad graduate program. The interviews were each 30 minutes long and consisted of describing my research, my goals for graduate school, and what I was looking for in a graduate institution. Each professor explained their research and I asked questions to them about their research.

title: CO Solution Center Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) in Mar 2014
Interview Descriptions:
Very straight forward process.  Applied initially online via the UCSF website, contacted about two weeks later to schedule a phone screening with the direct supervisor and the individual who previously held the position prior to promotion.  (1st PLUS: internal opportunities for lateral/horizontal growth).  

Phone interview consisted of: (1) UCSF and departmental context e.g. recent achievements, intra-office growth; (2) reiteration of the position; (3) detailed description of my professional and academic profile, as it relates to the opportunity.  Very personable, concise answers, direct (2nd PLUS: effective communication, knowledgeable about the position, confident/clear expectations going forward).  

The in-person interview was scheduled about two to three weeks after the initial phone screening.  Panel interview consisted of the two individuals who conducted the phone screening and the Controller's Office Customer Service Manager.  Interview was refreshingly straight forward.  All three individuals were generous with their time, communicated and answered questions mindfully.  At closing, each shared an example of a personal interest/hobby, which I enjoyed hearing about.   I left with a clear understanding of the position, what the department sought to do going forward with the position, as well as the expectations of all involved.  Well worth the afternoon of lost pay to make these connections.  Gave me some insight to the hiring process at least.

title: Analyst IV Supervisor Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at UC San Francisco (San Francisco, CA)
Interview Descriptions:
The interview process is slow and plodding, which generally reflects the manner in which the whole system works.   The following is SOP for most open positions within the organization.

Ten days after I submitted my resume online, I received a phone call inquiry and 10 minute phone screening.  

The first interview was with that person and one of her supervisors in a joint, one-hour interview, which was friendly and thorough.  I received a tour of the department and a fleeting introduction to some of the staff, and a second interview was scheduled the following week.

I received an email notification requesting contact information for up to 5 references from the assigned recruiter from  the HR Department.  An evaluation with a graduated scale is sent to those individuals to complete, along with a few free form questions like: What are the candidate's three strongest attributes? allows for more personalized descriptors.  

They do contact your references directly and have a conversation with them.  If you work within a large organization, it is required that they have some feedback from direct supervisors and not other departmental supervisors, even if they worked closely with you.  

The second interview is for the final top 2 candidates, and is always a panel interview.  This one was conducted in 3 different sessions with a total of six employees with roles ranging from support - supervisor.  

A week after the second interview, I received a call with their decision to hire the other candidate and thanking me for my time. 

If you are asked for a second interview, you will receive updates, questions and decisions via email and phone.  If you're not asked for a second interview during the first one or within 48 hours of it, most likely they are moving on with other options.

I applied as an outside candidate for this management position, which is difficult to do at this level, but not impossible.  Priority is given to internal candidates, and most employees acclimate to the system and don't often leave, so the culture shock can be jarring.
Interview Questions:
There were no difficult questions, just a variety of standards and common sense, general inquiries.  If you know your field and are qualified for the first interview, it's rather uneventful.  No roleplaying; but some situationally specific scenarios are usually presented.  

What do you do if not everybody plays together well in the sandbox?
What is your management style?
How do you handle patients who are upset?
